function_call.name: eval_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":["Inadequate ventilation leading to increased risk of sars-cov-2 transmission","Inability to maintain social distancing in small businesses","Unsanitary conditions in the built environment","Lack of ventilation and air circulation","Potential transmission of contagious diseases","Poor ventilation and air circulation in the built environment","Lack of surface hygiene and cleaning protocols","Inadequate social distancing and overcrowding","High occupant density facilitates the accrual of human-associated microorganisms","Increased exposure risk associated with high occupant density and consistent contact demonstrated in covid-19 outbreaks","High transmissibility of covid-19 in confined spaces within the built environment","Resuspension of viral particles due to natural and mechanical airflow patterns in the built environment","Transfer of viruses from individuals to surfaces and vice versa through contact","Contamination of fomites with sars-cov-2 particles from infected individuals and bodily secretions","Survival of sars-cov-2 on different surfaces, indicating potential for fomite transmission","Potential transmission of sars-cov-2 through fecal-oral pathway","Possibility of sars-cov-2 transmission through aerosols","Transmission of sars-cov-2 and other contagious diseases through droplets and aerosolization in the built environment","Inadequate filtration techniques for removing pathogens like sars-cov-2 from shared air environments.","Close contact and spatial proximity with infected persons","Inadequate use and handling of masks","Lack of implementation of social distancing measures in local communities","Inadequate understanding and implementation of environmental precautions","The spread of sars-cov-2 through aerosolized water droplets from sink areas","Ineffective handwashing and hand sanitizing protocols","Potential for spread of sars-cov-2 in buildings due to viral particles associated with larger particles that can potentially penetrate high efficiency filters.","Increasing outside air fractions may lead to increased energy consumption","Not all air-handling systems have capacity to substantially increase outside air ratios","High airflow rates without increased outside air fraction can increase transmission potential of contagious diseases","Higher rh decreases airborne dispersal of viral particles","Higher humidity negatively impacts lipid-enveloped viruses through interactions with the polar membrane heads","Changes in humidity impact susceptibility to infection and viral particle deposition in the respiratory tract","Risk of overhumidification increasing the potential of mold growth","Increased rh may lead to increased buildup on filters, decreasing airflow","Effectiveness of capturing viral particles is increased with increased rh, but may lead to overhumidification","Increased window ventilation may expose occupants to extreme temperature profiles.","Close proximity in buildings may promote potential viral transfer from one residence to another.","Insufficient understanding of the impact of natural light on sars-cov-2 indoors.","Exposure to uvc light can pose safety concerns for room occupants if not properly installed or used.","Unexplored effects of daylight on indoor viruses and sars-cov-2 could lead to a lack of effective mitigation strategies.","Inadequate implementation of spectrally tuned electric lighting for disinfection indoors could lead to ineffective virus inactivation.","Uvc and uvgi light disinfectant strategies for buildings may have unintended consequences if not implemented with appropriate precaution.","Spatial configurations designed to encourage social interactions may inadvertently enhance opportunities for transmission of viruses.","Limited options for social-distancing measures in health care facilities","Cohousing patients with vastly different requirements","Positively pressurized protective environment pe rooms","Potential migration of aerosols from patient rooms into higher traffic corridors, increasing the risk of spreading airborne pathogens.","Involuntary exposure of room occupants to airborne pathogens from occupants of the corridor space due to negative pressure differentials.","Drawbacks of anterooms in pe or aii rooms, including increased floor area, travel distance, and visual barrier between patients and care teams.","Inadequate consideration of general facility design for different patient conditions and operational requirements may lead to increased risk of viral transmission within the hospital or healthcare facility.","Increase in the number of individuals contracting covid-19 and being exposed to sars-cov-2","Limited effectiveness of filtration techniques against pathogens such as sars-cov-2","Viral particles too small for best filters","Imperfect filter systems","Unidentified symbols and characters could indicate potential security risks or data corruption.","Unidentified text content","Transmission of sars-cov-2 virus through droplets and fomites","Airborne spread of sars-cov-2 virus during aerosol-generating procedures","Uncertain role of the faecal-oral route in sars-cov-2 transmission","Environmental sampling conducted in an airborne infectious-disease zone in a hospital.","Use of bioaerosol samplers in a hospital environment can lead to potential aerosolized pathogen exposure.","Lack of dedicated covid-19 patient hospital infrastructure","Inadequate ventilation in patient rooms","Insufficient air-cleaning routes in the airborne infectious-disease zone","Inadequate ventilation in the corridor","Negative pressure in the ward","Inadequate cleaning and disinfection schedule","High number of positive air and surface samples indicating potential contamination","Positive samples from isolation rooms indicate potential spread of the virus to other areas","Toilet identified as the most contaminated environment","Presence of viral particles in bathroom surfaces and aerosols","Contamination of hands during toilet usage","Generation of bio-aerosols in drainage stacks after toilet flushing","Contamination and spread of viruses in the toilet area due to shared use by multiple patients, potentially leading to a higher risk of infection.","High transfer rate of viruses from smooth to rough surfaces may contribute to contamination in the toilet area.","Detection of positive samples in the toilet area and potential presence of sars-cov-2 in patient stool samples present an increased risk of viral spread in the built environment.","Leakage of aerosols from isolation rooms to the corridor","Detection of weakly positive virus in corridor air and on exhaust grilles","Low airborne concentration of sars-cov-2 in the hospital","Presence of aerosols in the bathroom","Detection of sars-cov-2 in an air-outlet fan","Small number of collected air samples","Indoor air-temperature and relative humidity within a range favorable for microbial growth."]}
